channel.name: How deterministic are the smart contracts and zkPrograms when they are compiled?

messages.content:
Will I always get the same prover and verification keys as long as I use the same code?

What happens when there are breaking changes between one o1js version and another? Will it be necessary to keep using the old version?

No, the prover and verification keys depend upon
- Your code and everything it uses (for example, env variables can affect the verification keys in some cases)
- o1js version, and sometimes some changes break your verification keys even when the major version is the same (o1js 1.2 -> 1.3 is such example as they fixed some bugs in 1.3)
- mina node version (an example: changes in mina node on devnet in January 2024 have broken some of my contracts).

In general, it is better to have an upgrade strategy as you may also want to fix bugs in your contract's code and set the permissions at least to
```setVerificationKey:
     Permissions.VerificationKey.impossibleDuringCurrentVersion()``` to be able to upgrade when the mina node changes, which is expected during the next hardfork.
I see. Could you expand on what are you doing by setting the verification key with `impossibleDuringCurrentVersion` and how that fits within an upgrade strategy?
There is a good description in o1js code: https://github.com/o1-labs/o1js/blob/main/src/lib/mina/account-update.ts#L266
If I understand correctly, it makes the contract impossible to upgrade as long as there's no hard fork that breaks the current verification key, right?

In general, yes. But it does not help you when o1js introduce breaking changes or you find the bugs in your code, so you have three options here
- Keep signature authorization to be able to upgrade. It will decrease the trust in your contract, but it is ok at the early stage of the project
- Upgrade by moving or copying the data to new contract
- Create new contract and maintain two contracts in the same time
There is a good article on it: https://docs.minaprotocol.com/zkapps/writing-a-zkapp/introduction-to-zkapps/secure-zkapps

Thanks, I'll give it a read, although the lack of backwards compatibility with old smart contracts and dependence on active maintenance seems like a big issue, specially for zkApps that manage funds. Once deployed a contract should be able to be used forever with no further intervention

Mina is an advanced-proof technology in the early development stage and is being developed at a fast pace. Putting such limitations will limit the progress. How many MS-DOS programs do you want to run now on your modern Mac? Probably none.

I hear you on being able to advance at a fast pace, but eventually it should be able to sustain a deployed contract forever. Operating systems for personal computers usually don't manage the funds, authentication, platform rules, etc of other people. And even mainframes that weren't designed with trustlessness in mind are  expected to able to run algol/cobol/etc code written decades ago
We can support a deployed contract forever with permissions that allow for upgrade paths, or you can fork the current version of Mina and run a network with your smart contract forever.

We can actually calculate this: what is the value in MINA grants necessary for upgrading existing on mainnet right now contracts and what value to the ecosystem Mina protocol upgrades will bring? The difference is 100000x I guess, so MF would be willing simply fund the mainnet contract upgrade process at this stage. It will not be expensive.
Can these upgrades be done trustlessly tho?
Theoretically you can have multisig there, but I do not have code examples
MDA can, for example, manage such multisig staff @flushthefashion

And "just fork mina and run your own blockchain to keep supporting your contract" can't be the answer, since that would be operationally complex and costly, would defeat the whole purpose of mina as a consensus layer, and at the end you are basically just trusting the team that orchestrates the whole fork, so you may as well just make the contract upgradeable and trust the team with the keys
Multisigs aren't considered trustless
I think what we should aspire to is reaching a point where prover and verification keys deployed at some point are guaranteed to be supported forever

I think the correct framing will be backwards compatibility, with loss of performance as we upgrade the system.  We need Mina to be like 100x faster, support more state, allow more contraints in the proofs.  If a breakthrough new tech is discovered in zk research, we need to incorporate that into our product.

If you produce a proof with a trusted copy of a zkprogram, and someone has changed the VK on chain to be malicious, you won't be able to produce a valid proof.  So only users who are aware of the upgrade will be forced to use the upgraded smart contract.  Also, by using the impossibleInCurrentVersion permission, you essentially make all the same guarantees, as long as Mina never upgrades.

Sorry if this came off too harsh, let me clarify:

Unupgradable contracts are a good option to have.  _Some_ way of enforcing non-upgradability forever would be a good thing to have.  _Specifically_ guaranteeing that a given prover and verification key pair will always be valid would limit the innovation space for Mina, and I don't agree with that approach.

Some features that we already have are:
- send, receive, updateState are their own permissions and can't be upgraded with a verification key.  So this already stops some attacks
- Upgraded contracts will not work with users' cached contracts unless the user also upgrades, so there is clear communication that an upgrade has occurred.
- Users can fork Mina and run the current version forever, allowing for the impossible permission to be set on upgrades

Another interesting feature we could see would be for the next version of the proving system that comes out to have a non-native prover and verifier for the previous proving system.  That would allow for backwards compatibility.  This would be a lot of work, but I think it is an ideal solution idealistically.

> Another interesting feature we could see would be for the next version of the proving system that comes out to have a non-native prover and verifier for the previous proving system.  That would allow for backwards compatibility.  This would be a lot of work, but I think it is an ideal solution idealistically.

Exactly, I'm not familiar enough with how everything works under the hood but I imagine there are workarounds to implement backwards compatibility to be able to set things on stone without the need for active management (and trust). And I'm not saying that this should be implemented tomorrow, but I think it's a very important goal and something to be aware of as a dev and as a user.
